case_vignette: A 32-year-old white woman who has n   ever smoked presents with pruritic, tender, erythematous, violaceous patches with eczema-like blisters on her upper, lateral    thighs.    In 2012, she began traveling annually  from Pennsylvania    to South Carolina, from January through  April, where she works with and rides horses daily from morning to evening. Her symptoms    began in her first year in South Carolina and  appear consistently from January through March. Her lesions appear initially in mid-January as a red dot    and   progress by mid-February. They resolve sponta   neously in March.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_frq: Equestrian perniosis (also known as equestrian cold panniculitis)

I have itchy, tender, red to purple patches with some blistery spots on my upper, outer thighs.

The symptoms began in my first year in South Carolina and appear consistently from January through March each year.

Yes, they resolve spontaneously in March without any scarring.

Yes, the symptoms appear when I am in South Carolina working with and riding horses daily from morning to evening.

Yes, the affected areas on my upper, lateral thighs would typically be in contact with the saddle or riding gear.
Final Diagnosis: Equestrian perniosis.

I have itchy, tender, red to purple patches with blisters similar to eczema on my upper, outer thighs.

I don't have any known allergies to plants or metals.
